sen.j: 年神（としがみ、歳神とも）は、神道の神 (神道)である。
sen.e: "Toshigami"(年神, also written as 歳神) is a Shinto god (Shinto).
"Toshigami"(年神, also written as 歳神) is a Shinto god (Shinto).
"Toshigami"(年神, also written as 歳神) is a Shinto god (Shinto).

sen.j: 毎年正月に各家にやってくる来方神である。
sen.e: He (or she) is a raiho-shin (visiting god) visiting homes every New Year's Day.
He (or she) is a raiho-shin (visiting god) visiting homes every New Year's Day.
He (or she) is a raiho-shin (visiting god) visiting homes every New Year's Day.

sen.j: 地方によってはお歳徳(とんど)さん、正月様、恵方神、大年神（大歳神）、トシドン（としどん）、年爺さん、若年さんなどとも呼ばれる。
sen.e: Different regions call him (or her) Otondo-san, Shogatsu-sama, Eho-gami, Otoshi no kami, Toshidon, Toshi jisan, Wakadoshi-san, etc.
Different regions call him (or her) Otondo-san, Shogatsu-sama, Eho-gami, Otoshi no kami, Toshidon, Toshi jisan, Wakadoshi-san, etc.
Different regions call him (or her) Otondo-san, Shogatsu-sama, Eho-gami, Otoshi no kami, Toshidon, Toshi jisan, Wakadoshi-san, etc.

sen.j: 「年」は稲の実りのことで、穀物神である。
sen.e: "Toshi" refers to harvest of rice, and he (or she) is a grain god.
"Toshi" refers to the harvest of rice, and he (or she) is a grain god.
Toshi' refers to the harvest of rice, and he (or she) is a grain god.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更しました。

sen.j: その根底にあるのは、穀物の死と再生である。
sen.e: At the root is death and rebirth of grains.
At the root is the death and rebirth of grain.
At the root is the death and rebirth of grain.

sen.j: 古代日本で農耕が発達するにつれて、年の始めにその年の豊作が祈念されるようになり、それが年神を祀る行事となって正月の中心行事となっていった。
sen.e: In ancient Japan, with the development of agriculture, prayers at the beginning of the year for abundant crop during the year began, and developed to an event honoring Toshigami, which became the main event for New Year's.
In ancient Japan, with the development of agriculture, prayers at the beginning of the year for an abundant crop began, and developed to honor Toshigami, which became the main event for New Year's.
In ancient Japan, with the development of agriculture, prayers at the beginning of the year for an abundant crop began, and developed to honor Toshigami, which became the main event for New Year's.

sen.j: 現在でも残る正月の飾り物は、元々年神を迎えるためのものである。
sen.e: The New Year's decorations remaining today, were originally for welcoming Toshigami.
The New Year's decorations used today, were originally for welcoming Toshigami.
The New Year's decorations used today, were originally for welcoming Toshigami.

sen.j: 門松は年神が来訪するための依代であり、鏡餅は年神への供物であった。
sen.e: Kadomatsu (New Year's pine decoration) is an object to which the Toshigami is drawn, and the mirror-shaped rice cake was an offering for Toshigami.
Kadomatsu (New Year pine tree branch decoration) is an object to which the Toshigami is drawn, and the mirror-shaped rice cake was an offering to Toshigami.
Kadomatsu (New Year pine tree branch decoration) is an object to which the Toshigami is drawn, and the mirror-shaped rice cake was an offering to Toshigami.

sen.j: 各家で年神棚・恵方棚などと呼ばれる棚を作り、そこに年神への供え物を供えた。
sen.e: Families built shelves called toshigamidana or ehodana, and placed the offering for Toshigami there.
Families built shelves called toshigamidana or ehodana, and placed the offering for Toshigami there.
Families built shelves called toshigamidana or ehodana, and placed the offering for Toshigami there.

sen.j: また一方で、年神は家を守ってくれる祖先の霊、祖霊として祀られている地方もある。
sen.e: Meanwhile, in some regions, Toshigami is honored as sorei, or ancestral spirits protecting the household.
Meanwhile, in some regions, Toshigami is honored as sorei, or ancestral spirits protecting the household.
Meanwhile, in some regions, Toshigami is honored as sorei, or ancestral spirits protecting the household.

sen.j: 農作を守護する神と家を守護する祖霊が同一視されたため、また、田の神も祖霊も山から降りてくるとされていたため（山の神も参照）である。
sen.e: It is because the god protecting agriculture and the god protecting the family were equated, and deity of rice fields and harvests was also believed to descend from the mountains (refer to mountain god).

It is because the god protecting agriculture and the god protecting the family were equated, and the deity of rice fields and harvests were also believed to descend from the mountains (refer to mountain god).

It is because the god protecting agriculture and the sorei protecting the family were equated, and the deity of rice fields and harvests and the sorei were also believed to descend from the mountains (refer to mountain god).
sen.cmt: 「祖霊」を加え、一部文章を変更しました。

sen.j: 柳田國男は、一年を守護する神、農作を守護する田の神、家を守護する祖霊の3つを一つの神として信仰した素朴な民間神が年神であるとしている。
sen.e: Kunio YANAGITA considered the three gods, god protecting the year, deity of rice fields and harvests protecting agriculture, and sorei protecting the household, worshipped as one simple folk god, as Toshigami.

Kunio YANAGITA considered the three gods, god protecting the year, deity of rice fields and harvests protecting agriculture, and sorei protecting the household, to be worshipped as one simple folk god, as Toshigami.

Kunio YANAGITA considered the three gods, god protecting the year, deity of rice fields and harvests protecting agriculture, and sorei protecting the household, to be worshipped as one simple folk god, as Toshigami.

sen.j: 中世ごろから、都市部で「年神（歳神）」は「年徳神（歳徳神）」と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Around the middle ages, 'Toshigami (年神 or 歳神)' began being referred to as 'Toshitoku-jin (年徳神 or 歳徳神).'
Around the middle ages, 'Toshigami (年神 or 歳神)' began being referred to as 'Toshitoku-jin (年徳神 or 歳徳神).'
Around the middle ages, 'Toshigami (年神 or 歳神)' began being referred to as 'Toshitoku-jin (年徳神 or 歳徳神).'

sen.j: 徳は得に通じ縁起が良いとされたためである。
sen.e: Toku (徳: virtue) leads to toku (得: profit) and was considered good luck.
Toku (徳: virtue) leads to toku (得: profit) and was considered good luck.
Toku (徳: virtue) leads to toku (得: profit) and was considered good luck.

sen.j: 方位にも取り入れられ、歳徳神のいる方角は「恵方」と言って縁起の良い方角とされるようになった。
sen.e: It was also adopted in direction, and the direction of Toshitoku-jin was called 'eho (favorable direction)' and was considered a direction bringing good luck.
It was also adopted in direction, and the direction of Toshitoku-jin was called 'eho (favorable direction)' and was considered a direction that brings good luck.
It was also adopted in direction, and the direction of Toshitoku-jin was called 'eho' (favorable direction) and was considered a direction that brings good luck.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションの位置を変更しました。

sen.j: 暦には女神の姿をした歳徳神が描かれているが、神話に出てくる大年神は男神であり、翁の姿をしているともされる。
sen.e: In the almanac, Toshitoku-jin is depicted as a female god, but Otoshi no kami in myths is a male god, and some say he appears as an old man.
In the almanac, Toshitoku-jin is depicted as a female god, but the mythical Otoshi no kami is a male god, and some say he appears as an old man.
In the almanac, Toshitoku-jin is depicted as a female god, but the mythical Otoshi no kami is a male god, and some say he appears as an old man.

sen.j: 元々民間信仰の神であり、その姿は様々に考えられていたということである。
sen.e: Originally a god of folk belief, there was variation in people's perception of his (or her) figure.
Originally a god of folk belief, there was variation in people's perception of his (or her) figure.
Originally a god of folk belief, there was variation in people's perception of his (or her) figure.

sen.j: 大年神・御年神
sen.e: Otoshi no kami and Mitoshi no kami
Otoshi no kami and Mitoshi no kami
Otoshi no kami and Mitoshi no kami

sen.j: 日本神話では、スサノオと神大市比売（かむおおいちひめ。オオヤマツミの娘）の間に生まれた大年神（おおとしのかみ）としている。
sen.e: In Japanese myth, he (or she) is believed to be Otoshi no kami, who was born between Susanoo and Kamu-oichi-hime (daughter of Oyamatsumi).
In Japanese mythology, he (or she) is believed to be Otoshi no kami, who was born between Susanoo and Kamu-oichi-hime (daughter of Oyamatsumi).
In Japanese mythology, he (or she) is believed to be Otoshi no kami, who was born between Susanoo and Kamu-oichi-hime (daughter of Oyamatsumi).

sen.j: 両神の間の子にはほかにウカノミタマがおり、これも穀物神である。
sen.e: These gods had another child, Ukano-mitama, who is also a grain god.
These gods had another child, Ukano-mitama, who is also a grain god.
These gods had another child, Ukano-mitama, who is also a grain god.

sen.j: また、大年神と香用比売（カヨヒメ）の間の子に御年神（みとしのかみ、おとしのかみ）、孫に若年神（わかとしのかみ）がおり、同様の神格の神とされる。
sen.e: Additionally, Otoshi no kami and Kayo-hime had a child, Mitoshi no kami (or Otoshi no kami), and a grandchild, Wakatoshi no kami, who were gods of similar divinity.
Additionally, Otoshi no kami and Kayo-hime had a child, Mitoshi no kami (or Otoshi no kami), and a grandchild, Wakatoshi no kami, who were gods of similar divinity.
Additionally, Otoshi no kami and Kayo-hime had a child, Mitoshi no kami (or Otoshi no kami), and a grandchild, Wakatoshi no kami, who were gods of similar divinity.

sen.j: 大年神は他に多くの神の父とされている。
sen.e: Otoshi no kami is believed to be the father of many other gods.
Otoshi no kami is believed to be the father of many other gods.
Otoshi no kami is believed to be the father of many other gods.

sen.j: それだけ重要な神とされていたことがわかる。
sen.e: This shows what important god he was.
This shows what an important god he was.
This shows what an important god he was.

sen.j: 伊怒比売（いのひめ、神活須毘神（かむいくすび）の娘）との間の子
sen.e: Children between Ino-hime (daughter of Kamu-ikusubi no kami)
Children between Ino-hime (daughter of Kamu-ikusubi no kami)
Children between Ino-hime (daughter of Kamu-ikusubi no kami)

sen.j: 大国御魂神（おほくにみたま） - 国土の神霊の意
sen.e: Ohokuni-mitama - means divine spirit of the country
Ohokuni-mitama - means divine spirit of the country
Ohokunimitama no kami - means divine spirit of the country
sen.cmt: 他の「○○神」の表記と統一するため、Ohokunimitama no kamiとしました。

sen.j: 韓神（から） - 朝鮮からの渡来氏族が信仰した神
sen.e: Kara - god worshipped by clans from Korea
Kara - god worshipped by clans from Korea
Kara no kami - god worshipped by clans from Korea

sen.j: 曾富理神（そほり） - 新羅の王都（ソウル）の意か
sen.e: Sohori no kami - believed to be the imperial capital of Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) (Seoul)
Sohori no kami - believed to be the imperial capital of Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) (Seoul)
Sohori no kami - believed to be the imperial capital of Silla (ancient Korean kingdom) (Seoul)
sen.cmt: Shiragiは新羅の日本語読みであるため、Sillaに修正しました。

sen.j: 新しい室を建てて葛の綱で結ぶの意。
sen.e: Means building a new room and tying with arrowroot rope.
Means building a new room and tying with arrowroot rope.
Means building a new room and tying with arrowroot rope.

sen.j: 新嘗祭のための屋舎を建てることと考えられる
sen.e: Believed to be about building a building for Niinamesai (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities).
Believed to be about constructing a building for Niinamesai (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities).
Believed to be about constructing a building for Niinamesai (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities).

sen.j: 記紀には系譜以外の事績の記述がないが、古語拾遺には、大地主神（おおとこぬしのかみ）の田の苗が御年神の祟りで枯れそうになったので、大地主神が白馬・白猪などを供えて御年神を祀ると苗は再び茂ったという説話がある。
sen.e: There is no description other than of the genealogy in the Kiki (Kojiki and Nihonshoki), but in the Kogoshui, there is a story about the rice seedling in Otokonushi no kami's rice field almost running dry due to a curse by Mitoshi no kami, and how they grew back when Otokonushi no kami prayed to Mitoshi no kami with offerings of white horse and white hog.

There is no description other than of the genealogy in the Kiki (Kojiki and Nihonshoki), but in the Kogoshui, there is a story about the rice seedling in Otokonushi no kami's rice field that is almost running dry due to a curse by Mitoshi no kami, and how they grew when Otokonushi no kami prayed to Mitoshi no kami with offerings of a white horse and a white hog..

There is no description other than of the genealogy in the Kiki (Kojiki and Nihonshoki), but in the Kogoshui (Gleaning of Ancient Words), there is a story about the rice seedling in Otokonushi no kami's rice field that is almost running dry due to a curse by Mitoshi no kami, and how they grew when Otokonushi no kami prayed to Mitoshi no kami with offerings of a white horse and a white hog..
sen.cmt: 古語拾遺の補足を入れました。(参考: http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=2fsCe699Ze8C&pg=PA19&dq=kogo-shui&lr=&as_brr=3#)

sen.j: 大年神は大歳御祖神社（静岡県静岡市葵区）、飛騨一宮水無神社（岐阜県高山市）などで祀られている。
sen.e: Otoshi no kami is enshrined in Otoshimioya-jinja Shrine (Aoi Ward, Shizuoka City, Shizuoka Prefecture), Hidaichinomiyaminashi-jinja Shrine (Takayama City, Gifu Prefecture), etc.
Otoshi no kami is enshrined in Otoshimioya-jinja Shrine (Aoi Ward, Shizuoka City, Shizuoka Prefecture), Hidaichinomiyaminashi-jinja Shrine (Takayama City, Gifu Prefecture), etc.
Otoshi no kami is enshrined in Otoshimioya-jinja Shrine (Aoi Ward, Shizuoka City, Shizuoka Prefecture), Hida Ichinomiya Minashi-jinja Shrine (Takayama City, Gifu Prefecture), etc.
sen.cmt: 区切れを入れ、Hida Ichinomiya Minashi-jinja Shrineとしました。

sen.j: また、特に西日本で大歳神社・大歳様として田の畔の祠などに祀られている。
sen.e: He is also enshrined in small shrines on the ridge between rice fields as Otoshi-jinja Shrine, Otoshisama, particularly in western Japan.
He is also enshrined in small shrines on the ridge between rice fields as the Otoshi-jinja Shrine, Otoshisama, particularly in western Japan.
He is also enshrined in small shrines on the ridge between rice fields as the Otoshi-jinja Shrine, Otoshisama, particularly in western Japan.

sen.j: 葛城御歳神社（奈良県御所市）が大歳神社・御歳神社の総本社とされる。
sen.e: Katsuragimitoshi-jinja Shrine (Gose City, Nara Prefecture) is considered the chief shrine.
Katsuragimitoshi-jinja Shrine (Gose City, Nara Prefecture) is considered the chief shrine.
Katsuragi Mitoshi-jinja Shrine (Gose City, Nara Prefecture) is considered the chief shrine.
